Common Themes And Application:
- The theme of God's sovereignty and the futility of human rebellion is present in Psalm 2 and 1 Kings 21:20-29, highlighting the consequences of defying God's authority.
- The life application in these passages is to acknowledge and submit to God's authority in our lives, recognizing the futility of rebelling against Him.
- The theme of the coming of Elijah and the fulfillment of prophecy is seen in Mark 9:9-13, pointing to the significance of Jesus as the fulfillment of God's promises.
- The life application encourages us to have faith in Jesus as the fulfillment of God's promises and to listen to His teachings.
Symbols1Summarize: The most important recurring symbol in these verses is the image of God's anointed king, who is referred to as His "son." This symbol develops throughout the Bible, culminating in Jesus Christ, who is described as the ultimate fulfillment of this anointed king, who rules over the nations and brings salvation to all who take refuge in Him.
Symbols2Summarize: The most important symbol that recurs throughout the Bible in these verses is the act of selling oneself. In this passage, Ahab has "sold himself to do evil." This symbol of selling oneself to evil represents the idea of giving up one's allegiance to God and aligning with sin. Throughout the Bible, this symbol develops through various stories of individuals who choose to sell themselves to evil, ultimately facing consequences for their actions.
Symbols3Summarize: The most important symbol in these verses that recurs throughout the Bible is the imagery of Elijah. In this passage, the disciples ask why it is said that Elijah must come before the Son of Man. Jesus explains that Elijah has indeed come but has been mistreated, just as it was prophesied. This symbol of Elijah's coming and suffering develops throughout the Bible, representing a precursor to the suffering and rejection of Jesus himself.
Summarize1: In Psalm 2, the psalmist questions why the nations and peoples plot against the Lord and his anointed. But God laughs at them, for he has installed his king on Zion. God warns the rulers to serve him with fear and honor his son, or face destruction. Those who take refuge in God are blessed.
Summarize2: In this passage, Ahab is confronted by the prophet Elijah for his evil deeds. God pronounces judgment on Ahab and his descendants, but because Ahab humbles himself, God decides to postpone the disaster until the days of his son.
Summarize3: In Mark 9:9-13, Jesus tells his disciples not to tell anyone about what they saw until after his resurrection. The disciples discuss what it means for Jesus to rise from the dead and ask about the prophecy regarding Elijah. Jesus explains that Elijah does come first to restore all things, but the Son of Man must suffer and be rejected. He also reveals that Elijah has already come and has experienced everything that was written about him.
Behindinsights1:
Some interesting insights about this passage, when considering external research, include:

- The mention of "the Lord's anointed" in verse 2 refers to the Messiah, or the coming savior, who will be opposed by earthly rulers. This foreshadows the conflict between Jesus Christ and worldly powers during his ministry.

- The phrase "Let us break their chains and throw off their shackles" in verse 3 can be seen as a symbol of rebellion against God's authority. This passage can be interpreted as a warning against defying God's rule and trying to establish human independence.

- The mention of the Lord laughing and scoffing at the schemes of the nations (verse 4) reflects the idea that God's power is supreme and human efforts against Him are futile.

- Verse 7, where the Lord declares, "You are my son; today I have become your father," is seen as a Messianic reference in Christian theology. It points to Jesus Christ as the Son of God, who fulfills the divine plan.

- The call to "serve the Lord with fear" and "kiss his son" (verses 11-12) can be interpreted as a plea for obedience and submission to God's authority. It implies that those who reject this call will face consequences.

These insights provide additional context and deepen the understanding of the passage.
Behindinsights3:
Some interesting insights about this passage include:

1. The disciples were confused about what "rising from the dead" meant, indicating that they did not fully understand or comprehend Jesus' teachings about his coming death and resurrection.

2. Jesus identifies John the Baptist as the fulfillment of the prophesied role of Elijah. This highlights the connection between the Old Testament prophecies and the events surrounding Jesus' ministry.

3. The rejection and mistreatment of John the Baptist foreshadows the rejection and suffering that Jesus himself would face. This illustrates a pattern of resistance and persecution that would occur to those who proclaim the message of repentance and preparation for the coming of the Messiah.

4. Jesus' response also suggests that there is a deeper significance to his suffering and rejection that goes beyond the restoration brought by Elijah. This highlights the sacrificial role of Jesus as the Son of Man, who would ultimately bring salvation through his death and resurrection.
SocioSummary1: Psalm 2 was likely written during the time of the Israelite monarchy, possibly around the reign of David or Solomon. The psalm describes a situation of political tension and potential conflict between Israel and other nations or empires. The reference to breaking chains and throwing off shackles suggests a desire for independence or rebellion against the rule of God and His chosen leader. The geopolitical landscape of the Near East during this time was characterized by various political powers and shifting alliances.
SocioSummary2: The passage reflects the social and political climate of the kingdom of Israel under King Ahab. Ahab's reign is known for his marriage to Jezebel, a Phoenician princess, and the promotion of Baal worship. Ahab's rule was characterized by idolatry and disobedience to God, which is demonstrated through his evil actions and the influence of his wife. The passage highlights the conflict between the worship of Yahweh and other gods, as well as the negative outcomes of Ahab's sinful decisions.
SocioSummary3: During the 1st century AD, the region of Judea was under Roman rule, leading to tensions between the Jewish population and the Roman authorities. The Jewish religious authorities, referred to as the teachers of the law, played a significant role in interpreting and enforcing religious law. The question about Elijah's coming relates to the Jewish expectation of the Messiah, who was believed to be preceded by the prophet Elijah. Jesus acknowledges the coming of Elijah, but also emphasizes his own suffering and rejection, foreshadowing his crucifixion and resurrection.

Scene1: The scene from the movie that is similar to this passage is the climax of the film "Star Wars: Return of the Jedi." In this scene, Emperor Palpatine and Darth Vader conspire against the Rebel Alliance and the Jedi, seeking to break their resistance and maintain their control. However, Luke Skywalker, the chosen one, ultimately overpowers the Emperor, fulfilling his destiny and bringing balance to the Force.
Scene2: The scene from the movie that is similar to this passage is the scene in "The Lion King" where Scar confronts Simba after he discovers his evil deeds. Scar accuses Simba of causing the downfall of the Pride Lands, and Simba realizes the consequences of his actions. Similarly, Ahab is confronted by Elijah for his evil deeds and realizes the consequences that will befall him and his descendants. Both scenes involve the main characters facing the truth about their actions and their role in the downfall of their respective kingdoms.
Scene3: A similar scene from a movie is the one in "The Empire Strikes Back" where Luke Skywalker receives training from Yoda on the planet Dagobah. In this scene, Luke asks Yoda about the prophecy of the chosen one, and Yoda responds with a cryptic answer, explaining that there is balance in the Force and how he is not the only Jedi. The conversation between Jesus and his disciples mirrors this scene's tone and their discussions about prophecies and Elijah's coming.

emily1:
Why do the nations conspire and plot in vain?
Against the Lord and His anointed, a rebellious refrain.
They seek to break the chains, throw off the divine yoke,
But the One in heaven, with laughter, shall He poke.

For the rulers rise together, kings of the earth entwined,
In defiance of the Lord's command, their hearts maligned.
But the Lord, in anger, rebukes and terrifies their might,
His wrath, a tempest raging, as they stand in fright.

"I have installed my king, on Zion, holy and grand,
For he is my beloved son, by my side he'll stand.
Ask of me, and nations they shall be your domain,
The ends of the earth, your possession to attain."

With a rod of iron, the nations shall be shattered,
Like fragile pottery, to pieces they'll be scattered.
Wise are you, O kings, rulers of this earthly sphere,
Serve the Lord with trembling, His name always revere.

Celebrate His rule, but in fear, bow your head,
For His anger can ignite in a moment, dread.
Kiss His son, embrace his divine decree,
Take refuge in the Lord, blessed ever shall you be.
emily2:
In Ahab's heart, the seeds of evil sown,
A life consumed by sin, God's anger known.
With Jezebel, he danced with idols vile,
And led God's people down a treacherous aisle.

The Lord, in wrath, pronounced a dire decree,
To wipe out Ahab's house, his legacy.
No male shall linger, no descendant's breath,
For evil deeds have courted bitter death.

Ahab, in anguish, heard the prophet's words,
He tore his garments, humbled by the Lord.
In sackcloth clad, he fasted and he wept,
A glimmer of repentance, deeply kept.

The Lord, in mercy, saw this humbled man,
And stayed His hand, deferred a vengeful plan.
Yet, still the consequence would surely come,
Upon Ahab's house, a fate to succumb.

So let us ponder on this somber tale,
How choices made can make our lives derail.
May we, like Ahab, heed the warning clear,
And turn to God, before disaster nears.
emily3:
In silence they descended from the mount,
A truth too profound, a secret they kept,
Whispering among themselves, they did account,
The rising from the dead, in whispers crept.

With hearts heavy, they did question the law,
Why does Elijah come, is there a sign?
They sought answers, perplexed, their minds in awe,
As words of wisdom flowed from lips divine.

The Son of Man, He suffers and is scorned,
His fate sealed, fulfillment of ancient lore,
Elijah, too, by cruel hands was adorned,
They've done to him as written long before.

In pondered silence, lessons we may glean,
The path of suffering, from it we learn,
Beneath the surface, secrets yet unseen,
In sacred whispers, truth begins to yearn.

For what is life if not a mystery,
Where meanings hide beneath the surface deep,
In hushed moments, we find our hearts set free,
And in our seeking, divine truths may creep.

So let us tread in silence and explore,
The depths of wisdom, truths that resonate,
For in the whispers, wondrous truths restore,
Our souls uplifted, love to celebrate.
Snoop1:
Yo, listen up, I got a psalm for y'all to hear,
About the nations plottin' and conspirin' in fear.
The kings and rulers, they all unite,
Against the Lord, tryna put up a fight.

They say, "Let's break their chains, let's be free,
Throw off their shackles, and live carefree."
But the Lord in heaven, he just laughs,
Scoffs at their plans, puts 'em in a riff-raff.

He rebukes 'em in anger, terrifies 'em with wrath,
Says, "I got my king, on Zion's holy path."
He proclaims the decree, this is what he said,
"You are my son, I have become your dad."

Ask me, my son, and I'll make it real,
Nations as your inheritance, the whole deal.
Break 'em with a rod of iron, dash 'em like clay,
That's the power my anointed one will display.

So, you kings and rulers, listen up wise,
Serve the Lord with fear, let that rule rise.
Celebrate his kingdom, with trembling and respect,
Kiss his son, or your path will end in wreck.

His wrath can flare up in just a blink,
Blessed are those who take refuge, that's what I think.
So open your ears, and let this psalm sink in,
The Lord's got your back, he's your refuge and kin.
Snoop2:
Yo Ahab, my enemy, you found me,
But I found you, sold yourself to the dark deity,
The Lord gonna bring disaster, wipe out your lineage,
No male in Israel, slave or free, gonna face the blemish.

Your house gonna be like Jeroboam's and Baasha's fate,
Angered the Lord, made Israel's soul desecrate,
Jezebel gonna be devoured by them hounds,
In Jezreel, against the wall, she gonna be found.

Dogs gonna feast on Ahab's people in the city,
Birds gonna feed on those in the countryside, ain't pretty.
No one like Ahab, sold himself to wicked schemes,
Jezebel his wife, urging him towards evil extremes.

Ahab heard these words, tore his threads apart,
Put on sackcloth, fasted, humbled his heart.
Lived meekly, repenting for his vile deeds,
But the Lord saw his humility, his remorseful creeds.

Disaster won't come this day, for Ahab's sake,
But his house, his son, gonna feel the quake,
The Lord's vengeance won't fade away,
It'll fall on Ahab's lineage, come what may.
Snoop3:
Yo, yo, check it out, let me break it down
This here passage got some knowledge that's profound

Jesus laid down the law, told 'em what to do
Keep this on the low, don't let nobody knew
Until the Son of Man, risen from the dead

They puzzled, they wondered, what's this all about?
Talkin' 'bout risin' from the dead, got 'em full of doubt

So understand the message, let it resonate within

Don't keep it to yourself, spread the truth with pride
Jesus droppin' wisdom, let it be your guide. Yeah!

Christiansong3:
A Christian song that captures the sentiment and situation in the passage could be "Speak, O Lord" by Keith and Kristyn Getty. 

The lyrics of the chorus, in particular, resonate with the disciples' confusion and questions about Jesus' identity and mission:

"Speak, O Lord, as we come to You
To receive the food of Your Holy Word
Take Your truth, plant it deep in us
Shape and fashion us in Your likeness
That the light of Christ might be seen today
In our acts of love and our deeds of faith
Speak, O Lord, and fulfill in us
All Your purposes for Your glory"

This song emphasizes the disciples' desire for understanding and wisdom from God, much like their question about Elijah and the suffering of the Son of Man. It also speaks of God's purposes being fulfilled, which echoes Jesus' statement that Elijah has indeed come and suffered as prophesied.

applicationq1: What does it mean to serve the Lord with fear and celebrate his rule with trembling, as mentioned in Psalm 2:11? How can we apply this attitude of reverence and submission to our own lives and relationship with God?
applicationq2: How does the story of Ahab's repentance and humility challenge us to examine our own actions and attitudes towards God?
applicationq3: What can we learn from Jesus' response to the disciples' question about Elijah coming first before the Son of Man?
Enneagram1:
Type 8 (The Challenger)
- Identifies with the powerful figures that rise against the Lord and his anointed
- Feels a sense of rebellion and determination in the words "Let us break their chains and throw off their shackles"
- Relates to the Lord's confidence and strength expressed through laughter in the face of opposition

Type 6 (The Loyalist)
- Feels anxiety and concern about the conspiring nations and rulers
- Takes the Lord's rebuke and wrath literally, reflecting on the consequences of defying divine authority
- Internalizes the warning to serve the Lord with fear and trembling, seeking refuge in Him for protection and salvation
Enneagram2:
Type 1 (The Reformer):
- Is morally driven, so they may feel righteous anger towards Ahab for his evil deeds.
- May appreciate Elijah's straightforwardness in confronting Ahab.
- Could empathize with Ahab's action of tearing his clothes and fasting as a symbol of repentance.
- May feel satisfaction that Ahab's humility leads to temporary salvation.

Type 8 (The Challenger):
- Could resonate with Ahab's display of power and dominance before Elijah.
- May question the authority and righteousness of the Lord's judgment upon Ahab.
- Might view Ahab as weak for humbling himself before the Lord.
- Could interpret Ahab's ultimate punishment as a form of justice for his actions.
Enneagram3:
Type 5 (The Investigator):

- Analyzes the passage in depth, looking for hidden meanings and connections
- Questions Jesus' instruction to keep the experience secret until after his resurrection
- Asks why the teachers of the law believe Elijah must come before the Son of Man
- Deliberates on the significance and purpose of Elijah's role
- Re-evaluates Jesus' statement that Elijah has already come and the implications of his suffering and rejection

Type 9 (The Peacemaker):

- Accepts Jesus' instruction to keep the experience confidential without much resistance
- Seeks unity and harmony, avoiding potential conflicts arising from discussing the matter
- Curious about the teachers of the law's belief regarding Elijah's arrival before the Son of Man
- Encourages understanding and empathy, aiming to find common ground between the different perspectives
- Meditates on Jesus' explanation about Elijah's already fulfilled role and the importance of suffering and rejection

psychology1: One theme from this text is the rebellion of earthly rulers against divine authority. This theme can be related to findings in contemporary psychology research on the concept of power and authority. For example, studies have shown that individuals in positions of power can often display increased levels of aggression, resistance to authority, and a desire to challenge or rebel against established norms or rules. This highlights the inherent psychological tension between those in power and those under their authority.
psychology2: One theme from this text is the concept of personal responsibility and the consequences of one's actions. In contemporary psychology research, this theme aligns with the field of moral psychology, which focuses on the psychological processes involved in moral judgment and decision-making. Studies have shown that individuals who take responsibility for their actions and exhibit moral behavior are more likely to experience positive outcomes and a sense of well-being. (Source: Baumeister, R. F., & Exline, J. J. (1999). Virtue, personality, and social relations: Self-control as the moral muscle. Journal of Personality, 67(6), 1165-1194.)
psychology3: One theme from this text is the anticipation and fulfillment of prophecies. In contemporary psychology research, this theme can be related to the psychological concept of confirmation bias, where individuals tend to interpret information in a way that confirms their preexisting beliefs or expectations. This can influence perception and memory, as people may selectively remember or interpret events to fit their predictions or prophecies. Research by Nickerson (1998) and Klayman and Ha (1987) provides evidence for the presence of confirmation bias in various domains.
biology1:
Theme: The power and authority of God over the nations.

Scientific finding: One scientific finding that relates to the theme of the power and authority of God over the nations is the discovery of genomic imprinting in biology. Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic phenomenon where certain genes are marked differently depending on whether they are inherited from the mother or the father, leading to different expression patterns. This demonstrates the control and influence that genetics and parental inheritance have over an individual's traits and development.

Research sources:
- Feil, R., & Berger, S. L. (2007). Genomic imprinting in mammals: an interplay between chromatin and DNA methylation?. Trends in genetics, 23(8), 394-399.
- Ferguson-Smith, A. C., & Surani, M. A. (2001). Imprinting and the epigenetic asymmetry between parental genomes. Science, 293(5532), 1086-1089.
biology2:
Scientific Finding: The theme of cause and effect is reflected in the concept of gene-environment interactions in biology. Genetic factors and environmental factors both play a role in determining an individual's traits and susceptibility to diseases. Gene-environment interactions occur when the effects of genetic variations are modified by different environmental factors, such as diet, lifestyle, or exposure to toxins. This understanding highlights the complexity of biology and the need to consider both genetic and environmental factors in studying human health and disease.

Research Source: Nishida, N., & Nishida, H. (2020). Gene-environment interactions and their consequences for complex traits and diseases: a review of findings from animal models. Frontiers in Genetics, 11, 1016.
biology3:
Theme: Questioning and seeking understanding

Scientific Finding: Researchers have been studying the genetic basis of diseases to better understand their causes and develop effective treatments. For example, in the case of cancer, scientists have questioned why certain genetic mutations lead to the development of tumors. Through extensive research, they have identified specific gene mutations that drive cancer growth and are further seeking to understand their mechanisms and potential therapies.

Research sources:
1. Vogelstein, B., Papadopoulos, N., Velculescu, V. E., Zhou, S., Diaz, L. A., & Kinzler, K. W. (2013). Cancer genome landscapes. Science, 339(6127), 1546-1558.
2. Stratton, M. R., Campbell, P. J., & Futreal, P. A. (2009). The cancer genome. Nature, 458(7239), 719-724.
